ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Second- and third-order optical studies of 4-Bromoanilinium hydrogen phthalate single crystal for nonlinear optical device applications

Affiliation.OrgDivision: MRDL, PG and Research Department of Physics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A new organic NLO material 4-Bromoanilinium hydrogen phthalate was grown by slow evaporation technique. The solubility and metastable zone width were determined. The crystal belongs to monoclinic system with space group C2. Optical transmittance spectrum confirms the wide optical window. Absorption coefficient and band gap were calculated from transmittance. The thermal stability, laser-induced surface damage threshold and mechanical behaviour were analysed. The particle size-dependent second harmonic generation efficiency was evaluated by Kurtz–Perry powder method and existence of phase matching. The third-order optical study was measured by Z-scan studies. The dispersion of birefringence behaviour was studied.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Nonlinear optical (NLO) materials are suitable for frequency conversion, frequency mixing, optical data storage, electro-optic modulation, optical parametric oscillations and photonic integrated circuitry [1]. Organic materials are attractive due to high nonlinearities, ultra fast response and high damage threshold [2, 3]. To achieve good macroscopic nonlinear response in organic crystals, one requires high molecular hyperpolarizability and proper orientation of the molecule to facilitate high-frequency conversion efficiency. Most organic materials possess D–π–A type structure. For efficient SHG, a highly polarizable π-conjugated molecule substituted with strong electron donor, acceptor groups at the ends of molecule and noncentrosymmetric crystal structure are needed [4]. The 4-Bromoanilinium hydrogen phthalate (BAP) is synthesized as an intermediate product in the preparation of N-substituted phthalimides [5]. In the present investigation, we report the bulk growth, optical, thermal and mechanical studies of BAP single crystal for the first time.

Section2.Heading: Material synthesis
Section2.Para: The pure BAP material was synthesized from a saturated solution of ethanol containing 4-bromoaniline and phthalic acid in 1:1 stoichiometric ratio by the following reaction,

Section2.Heading: Solubility and metastable zone width
Section2.Para:
The solubility and metastable zone width studies were carried out in constant temperature water bath. The solution was stirred continuously for 6 h to achieve homogenization using an immersible magnetic stirrer. Solubility was determined by gravimetric analysis at different temperatures (30–50 °C) and the solubility curve of BAP is shown in Fig. 1. The plot of solubility vs. temperature exhibits a positive slope which is suitable for the growth of crystals both by slow cooling and slow evaporation methods [6].
Fig. 1
Solubility and nucleation curves of BAP crystal

Metastable zone width is an experimentally measurable quantity of factors, such as stirring rate, cooling rate of the solution and presence of additional impurities. The metastable zone width studies of BAP was carried out by poly thermal method [7]. The BAP solution (200 mL) saturated at 30 °C was prepared according to the solubility data and then the solution was filtered. The pure BAP solution was kept in constant temperature water bath and stirred continuously for 6 h for homogenization.

The solution was slowly cooled until the first speck appeared and recorded as nucleation temperature. The difference between saturation and nucleation temperature gives the metastable zone width of BAP in ethanol. The experiment was repeated for different saturation temperatures, like 35, 40, 45 and 50 °C 8]. The nucleation curve is shown in Fig. 1.

Section2.Heading: Seed preparation
Section2.Para:
The recrystallized salt was dissolved in ethanol at room temperature and optically transparent seed crystal of BAP was grown by slow evaporation method. The grown BAP crystals harvested after 24 days are shown in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2
BAP seed crystals

Section2.Heading: Growth from solvent slow evaporation technique
Section2.Para:
After careful selection of seed crystals, they were immersed into the mother solution using nylon thread to encourage further growth of bulk size crystals. Well-defined and transparent crystals of dimension 23 × 8 × 4 mm3 were grown in 44 days by slow solvent evaporation technique and shown in Fig. 3.
Fig. 3
BAP crystal grown by slow evaporation

Section1.Heading: Characterization studies
Section1.Para: The single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out for BAP crystal, using MESSRS ENRAF–NONIUS X-ray diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ = 0.7170 Å) radiation. Thermo gravimetric and differential thermal analyses (TG–DTA) were carried out to investigate the thermal stability of the crystal, using SDTQ600V8.3 instrument in nitrogen atmosphere. The indentation hardness was measured using shimadzu HMV-2000 fitted with Vikcer’s pyramidal indentor. The UV–vis–NIR transmittance spectrum for BAP crystal was measured using Shimadzu Model 1601 spectro-photometer. The second harmonic generation efficiency of BAP was measured by Kurtz and Perry powder technique [9].

Section2.Heading: Single crystal X-ray diffraction
Section2.Para: BAP single crystal was subjected to single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) analysis and unit cell parameters are a = 13.08 (14) Å, b = 7.81 (7) Å, c = 16.44 (14) Å, β = 106.67 (1)°, and the volume is found to be 1,412.11 (2) Å3. The crystal belongs to monoclinic system with space group C2.

Section2.Heading: Prediction of the crystal morphology
Section2.Para:
AS grown BAP crystal exhibits polyhedron morphology with eight symmetrically independent facets as shown in Fig. 4. The morphology of BAP crystal consists of eight well-developed faces out of which (0 0 1) is more prominent plane. The growth rate of BAP crystal along a- and b-axes was higher than that along the c-axis.
Fig. 4
Morphology of BAP crystal

Section2.Heading: Thermal properties
Section2.Para:
The thermal behaviour of BAP was studied by thermograviemetric analysis (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) using BAP sample of 7 mg. A thermal analyzer was employed at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in nitrogen atmosphere. The TG and DTA thermograms recorded in temperature range 30–500 °C are shown in Fig. 5. The DTA response curve shows a sharp endothermic peak at 168 °C, which coincides with the weight loss thermogram initiated at 150 °C in TG analysis.
Fig. 5
TG-DTA thermogram of BAP

This confirms that BAP starts to decompose at 150 °C. From the thermal study, it can be inferred that BAP crystal may be exploited for NLO applications up to 150 °C. The sharpness of weight loss thermogram can be attributed to the good degree of crystallinity and purity of BAP crystal.

Section2.Heading: Hardness
Section2.Para:
Measurement of hardness is a useful non destructive testing method employed to determine the applicability of the crystal in device fabrication. Hardness of the material is a measure of resistance it offers to local deformation [10]. The structure and composition of crystalline solids are inviolably related to mechanical hardness. Microhardness testing is one of the best methods of understanding the mechanical properties of the materials, such as fracture behaviour, yield strength, brittleness index and temperature of cracking [11, 12]. The microhardness value is calculated using the following relation: 1
$$ H_{\text{v}} = \frac{1.8544 P}{{d^{2} }}\left( {{{\text{kg}} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\text{kg}} {{\text{mm}}^{ 2} }}} \right. \kern-0pt} {{\text{mm}}^{ 2} }}} \right), $$
H v
=
1.8544 P
d 2
kg
kg
mm
2
mm
2
,
where ‘H v’ is the Vickers hardness number, ‘P’ is the applied load and ‘d’ is the average diagonal length of the indentation mark.

Indentations were made on the prominent (0 0 1) face of the sample after heat treating at different temperatures, such as room temperature, 333 and 373 K of the crystal, and the microhardness measurement was made for the applied loads varying from 10 to 60 g in steps of 10 g for the dwell time 15 s using Reichert Polyvar 2 MET microscope. The BAP crystal starts decomposing at 150 °C. The plots between the hardness number and the load at different temperatures are depicted in Fig. 6a. From the plot we clearly infer that the microhardness number increases with increasing the load and the microhardness number decreases with increasing the temperature. When the temperature increases, the average interatomic distance becomes greater due to lattice vibration. This leads to more and more lattice phonon interactions which causes the breaking of bond as well as reduce the hardness value [13]. The applied load and diagonal length ‘d’ of the indenter is related by Meyer’s law, P = ad
n [14], where the exponent ‘n’ is the Meyer’s index which is the measure of indentation size effect (ISE) and ‘a’ is constant. The exponent n < 2 is for normal ISE behaviour and n > 2 is for the reverse ISE behaviour. When n = 2, the hardness is independent of applied test load and is given by Kick’s law [15, 16]. The value of ‘n’ obtained for BAP crystal in the plane (0 0 1) at room temperature using linear fit between log P vs log d, shown in Fig. 6c is found to be 1.87. The microhardness value increases with increase in load which is in agreement with reverse indentation size effect (ISE) [17]. Onitsch [18] pointed that for hard materials ‘n’ lies between 1 and 1.6 and above 1.6 for soft materials. Since the value of ‘n’ for BAP is higher than 1.6, it is a soft material. From hardness value, the yield strength, σ y can be calculated [19]. The yield strength at room temperature for plane (0 0 1) is found to be 48.31 MPa. The elastic stiffness constant (C11) gives an idea about tightness of bonding between neighbouring atoms, for the plane (0 0 1) at different temperatures are calculated using Wooster’s [20] empirical formula C11 = H
v 7/4 . The trend of stiffness constant graph, shown in Fig. 6b, is similar to hardness number graph.
Fig. 6
a Hardness number vs load on (0 0 1) plane of BAP crystal. b Stiffness constant vs. Hardness number for (0 0 1) plane of BAP crystal. c Plot of log d vs. log P for (0 0 1) plane of BAP crystal

Section2.Heading: UV–Vis–NIR spectral studies
Section2.Para:
The optical transmission range, transparency cut-off and absorbance band are the most important optical parameters for laser frequency conversion applications. A BAP crystal of thickness 3 mm was used for UV–vis–NIR spectral study and the spectrum obtained is shown in Fig. 7a.
Fig. 7
a Response of % of Transmittance. b Plot of photon energy (hν) vs. (αhν) 2

The BAP crystal is optically transparent in the entire visible region with 80 % transmittance with cut-off wavelength at 389 nm. The transmission window in the visible region enables good optical transmission of the second harmonic frequencies of Nd:YAG laser. The measured transmittance (T) is used to calculate the absorption coefficient (α) using the following formula [21]: 2
$$ \alpha { = }\frac{{ 2. 3 0 3 {\text{ log}}\,\left( \frac{1}{T} \right)}}{t}, $$
α =
2.3 0 3
log
1 T
t
,
where ‘t’ is the thickness of the crystal and ‘T’ is transmittance of the crystal.

The optical absorption coefficient (α) near the absorption edge is given by the following equation [22]: 3
$$ \alpha hv = A\,(hv - E_{g} )^{\frac{1}{2}} , $$
α h v = A
( h v -
E g
)
1 2
,
where A is a constant, E g the optical band gap, h the Planck’s constant and ν the frequency of the incident photon. The Tauc’s graph [23] plotted between (αhν)2 with the photon energy (hν) at room temperature, shown in Fig. 7b, exhibits a linear behaviour that can be considered as the evidence of direct transition. Ideally the graph should be linear; the deviation from linearity at low incident photon energy can be attributed to the presence of irregularities and imperfection of the crystals. The intercept obtained by the extrapolation of the linear portion near the onset of absorption edge to the energy axis at (αhν)2 = 0. The band gap energy of the BAP crystal was estimated at 3.07 eV.

Section2.Heading: Refractive index
Section2.Para: The experimental value of refractive index of the BAP crystal was determined by Metricon model 2010/M prism coupler using the wave length of 632 nm. The refractive index is found to be 1.84.

Section2.Heading: Laser damage threshold
Section2.Para: The BAP crystal was mounted on the crystal holder in the path of the Nd:YAG laser beam and the energy of the beam was increased from 5 mJ. The crystal was exposed to the laser for a time period of 10 ns for all measurements. The spot size of the laser beam is 1 mm.

The surface damage threshold of the crystals was calculated using the Power density expression: 4
$$ P_{\text{d}} \text{ = }\frac{E}{{\tau \pi r^{2} }}, $$
P d
=
E
τ π
r 2
,
where ‘E’ is the energy (mJ), ‘τ’ the pulse width (ns) and ‘r’ the radius of the spot (mm). Multiple shot surface laser damage thresholds were determined in the prominent (0 0 1) plane. The mechanism of laser-induced damage in materials is often very complex involving various processes occurring in the materials, like electron avalanche, multi photon absorption, photo-ionization by thermal absorption [24], photo-chemical dissociation [25], electrostrictive fracture, etc. In addition, damage threshold depends on the external factors, such as irradiance, pulse duration, fluence, pulse repetition rate and experimental geometry. From an earlier report [26], it is known that in the long-pulse regime (τ > 100 ps), the damage is controlled by the rate of thermal conduction through the atomic lattice and in the short-pulse regime (τ < 100 ps), the optical break down and various nonlinear ionization mechanisms (multi-photon, avalanche multiplication, tunnelling) become important. Hence, thermal effects become important for the pulse widths that are in nano seconds and longer but in the case of pico second and femto second pulse widths, having higher repetition rates, the cumulative effects become prominent. In most of the cases, careful examination of the damage pattern gives some idea about the underlying mechanism of the laser-induced damage [27]. From the laser-induced damage pattern of BAP, shown in Fig. 8, tiny circular blobs surrounding the core of the damage indicate the damage is mainly due to thermal effects resulting in melting and solidification or decomposition of the material [24]. Recent investigations into laser damage in various optical materials by nano second pulses have shown that the temperature reached at the damage site could be as high as 12,000 K [28].
Fig. 8
Laser damage picture of BAP crystal for (0 0 1) Plane
Since BAP melts at around 150 °C, it is most likely that the damage occurs due to softening of the BAP crystal in the present case. Hence, in BAP we can expect the damage to be of thermal origin.

Section2.Heading: Nonlinear optical study
Section2.Para: A Q-switched Nd:YAG laser operating at 1,064 nm and 8 ns pulse width with an input repetition rate of 10 Hz and energy 31 mJ/pulse was used. The second harmonic signal generated in the crystalline sample was confirmed from the emission of green radiation of wavelength 532 nm. The SHG output was converted into electrical signal and displayed on digital storage oscilloscope. The optical signal incident on photo multiplier tube was converted into voltage output. The second harmonic signal of BAP crystalline material is 23 mV while that of standard KDP sample is 15.5 mV under similar conditions.

In addition to find the materials with noncentrosymmetric crystal structures, it is also used as a screening technique to identify the materials with the capability for phase matching. The continuous increase of SHG with increase of particle size and gets saturated confirms the phase matching behaviour of the material. Only those materials exhibiting a phase matching behaviour are grown into single crystals of large size for NLO applications [29]. To confirm the existence of phase matching property, the particle size dependency of SHG intensity was studied. The SHG efficiency has been shown to depend strongly on particle size [30, 31]. Single crystal of BAP was sieved using Sieve shaker (Model : Haver EML digital test sieve shaker) into distinct particle size range below 65, 65–125, 125–250, 250–350, 350–500 and above 500 μm. The particle size dependency of SHG intensity in BAP is shown in Fig. 9. The SHG intensity increases almost linearly with increase in particle size until 250–350 μm, above which (250–350 μm) it deviates from linearity and attain saturation. Hence, BAP is potentially a phase-matchable crystal which can be used as an efficient frequency doubler and optical parametric oscillator. The comparison of SHG efficiency data of BAP with different NLO crystals is presented in Table 1.
Fig. 9
Particle size vs. SHG output
Table 1

Section2.Heading: Z-scan measurements
Section2.Para:
The Z-scan method has gained swift acceptance by nonlinear optics community as a standard technique for accurate measurement of intensity-dependent nonlinear susceptibilities, nonlinear refractive index (NLR), n2 and nonlinear absorption coefficient (NLA), β. Figure 10a illustrates the Z-scan data for the closed aperture set up of BAP single crystal on (0 0 1) plane. The peak followed by a valley transmittance is the signature for negative nonlinearity [32] and is known as self-defocussing effect. This is due to local variation of refractive index with temperature. Figure 10b depicts the open aperture curve of BAP single crystal. Typical Z-scan data with open aperture are insensitive to nonlinear refraction. Therefore, the data are expected to be symmetric with respect to focus. For materials with multi-photon absorption, there is a minimum transmittance in focus (valley) and for saturable absorber sample, there is a maximum transmittance in the focus (peak). Multi-photon absorption suppresses the peak and enhances the valley, while saturation produces the opposite effect [33, 34]. The experimental observation shows a valley in the open aperture data which confirms the occurrence of multiphoton absorption in the BAP single crystal.
Fig. 10
a Plot of normal transmittance with closed aperture as a function of Z position. b Plot of normal transmittance with open aperture as a function of Z position

The measurable quantity ΔT p−v, the difference between the peak and valley transmittances, T p−T v as a function of |Δφ 0| is given by 5
$$ \left| {\Delta \varphi_{ 0} } \right| = \frac{{\Delta T_{{{\text{p}}\,{ - }\,{\text{v}}}} }}{{0.406\;(1\, - \,S)^{0.25} }}, $$

The estimated nonlinear refractive index (n 2), change in refractive index (Δn), absorption coefficient (β) and third-order susceptibility (χ (3)) values of BAP crystal are −4.26 × 10−6 cm2/W, −1.24 × 10−3, 0.0486 cm/W and 2.442 × 10−4 esu, respectively. The non-linear absorption is attributed to a multi-photon absorption process and the nonlinear refraction leads to the self-defocusing nature of the crystal.

Section2.Heading: Birefringence
Section2.Para:
Birefringence studies were carried out on the prominent plane (0 0 1) of the grown BAP crystal. The birefringence was calculated using the formula Δn = kλ/t, where ‘λ’ is the wavelength of the source used, ‘t’ is the thickness of the specimen and ‘k’ is the fringe order. The BAP crystal with thickness 0.24 mm was used for this measurement. The variation in birefringence across the sample cross sections per unit thickness was calculated from the interferogram, and was found to be as Δno−Δne = 1.105 × 10−2. The recorded spectrum of birefringence vs. wavelength is shown in Fig. 11. From this measurement, it is observed that the BAP crystal possesses good birefringence values in the visible wavelength region between 0.112 and 0.088.
Fig. 11
Plot of dispersion of birefringence with wavelength of AP crystal

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Optical quality single crystal of organic BAP was grown by slow evaporation method. The solubility and metastable zone width of the material were determined in ethanol. The grown BAP crystal was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis and it is found that the crystal belongs to monoclinic system with space group C2. An optical study shows that the crystal has wide transmission range with UV cut-off wave-length at 389 nm. The experimental value of refractive index of BAP crystal is 1.84. The multiple shot laser damage threshold study was carried out on the prominent (0 0 1) plane and the LDT value of BAP is 0.98 GW/cm2. The powder SHG effective nonlinearity of this material is confirmed with the emission of intense green light. Third-order nonlinear optical studies showed that the BAP crystal has defocusing nature with nonlinear refractive index and nonlinear absorption coefficient. In noncentrosymmetric space group materials, self-defocusing nature enhances good second harmonic generation. The birefringence value of BAP single crystal indicates good optical homogeneity. The promising crystal growth characteristics, physical and chemical properties of BAP crystal nominate it as a potential material for photonics, electro-optic and SHG device applications.
